Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project concerns the study of examples of topological gauge theories in low dimensions. Gauge theory, in special cases, is believed to underline the mathematical description of the universe; for example, the standard model for particle physics is a gauge theory in 4 dimensions. Much mathematical research into quantum physics over the last half-century has focussed on the analysis required to make accurate experimental predictions, but what was missed until the last decade or two was that topological (distance-independent) features of the theory are governed by an underlying algebra, which has some novel and unexplored features. The PI will study fundamental questions pertaining to this algebra in low dimension.

The main project aims at a rigid description of topological gauge theory (the so-called A-model) by the tested technique of mirror symmetry, which converts "soft" topological questions, defined up to coherent systems of homotopies, into rigid questions of analytic or algebraic geometry. The PI has a proposal for the mirror of pure gauge theory in 3 dimensions, which controls the gauging and 2-dimensional gauge theories such as arise from symplectic manifolds with Hamiltonian group actions. Another component of the research involves gauge theory in 3 dimensions, specifically Chern-Simons theory, which seems to lie half-way between the soft A- and the rigid B-model. Finally, a small project involving representation theory (geometric Langlands duality for algebraic curves) will be undertaken: the construction of a generic Langlands kernel for simply laced groups, which relies on cohomological and algebro-geometric techniques, but the subject is informed and inspired by electric-magnetic duality for gauge theory in 4 dimensions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project on Gauge Theory and Mirror Symmetry addresses foundational questions of symmetry in mathematics as applicable to physics. Perhaps confusingly, the interesting symmetries here are hiding in the gauge theory side: they are the continously varying internal symmetries of elementary particles which govern their physical interaction. (For mirror symmetry, see below.) The standard model of particle physics is such a gauge theory. The mathematics of the standard model is exceedingly difficult, and physicists have been studying its close relatives, where mathematical information is easier to extract. (These are known as supersymmetric gauge theories.)

Mathematics has been deeply influenced recently by the ability of these standard model relatives to produce interesting geometric and especially topological invariants for spaces of interest in algebraic geometry and representation theory.(Spaces are exotic geometric shapes, often defined as solution sets of algebraic equations; topology is geometry without the meter: it studies invariants ? numbers, but also other algebraic structures ? that are preserved under deformation.) Gauge symmetry in physics leads us to spaces which carry symmetries; conversely, the relevant set of symmetries (symmetry groups) can then be studied by means of the collection of spaces on which it acts. This perhaps counter-intuitive approach to symmetry is the subject of representation theory (an extremely successful and rapidly evolving enterprise.)

Just as the purpose of theoretical physics is to offer hard predictions for experimental data (such as particle scattering), abstract mathematical structures must normally be anchored down by rigid algebraic data. The simplest such would be a set of numbers ? analogous to parameter values for a physical system ? or, more generally, a function. For example, a group of symmetries on a linear space is often nailed down by its character, a function on the group. Thus, a rotation of a plane is deterimed by an angle θ; the character, which is cosθ, singles out the action of the rotation group on the plane.  Elsewhere, when the problem allows for continuous deformations, as in topological actions of groups, the data cannot be captured so rigicly by a function, and more subtle algebraic invariants must be constructed with no obvious geometric description.

The starting goal of the project has been the construction of such a character theory for symmetries that is relevant to physics in a 2-dimensional space-time (the simplest quantum field theories). The story sketched just above could be interpreted in terms of (the mathematically better understood) quantum mechanics. The surprising discovery was that, in this situation, the roles of geometric and topological symmetries are switched: topological symmetries are the ones allowing for a rigid character theory in terms of functions on geometric spaces, while the geometric symmetries are governed by more subtle, but less geometric, algebraic invariants. (In physics, they would be called A-model and B-model gauge theories.) The character theory itself is a consequence of a duality that has long been known in two-dimensional (2D) quantum physics, known as Mirror Symmetry. (A duality here is a dictionary between two different descriptions of the same physical theory.) In that language, my research describes the mirror dual of 2D topological gauge theory. 

The description of the 2D topological story has many parallels with the well-known one-dimensional geometric story. In particular, in both cases, a distinguished family of simple representations can be constructed from certain spaces (flag varieties) associated with the symmetry group, and every other representation of the symmetry decomposes into these simple constitutents. 

One gratifying feature was the interaction with higher-dimensional gauge theory ? quantum field theory in 3D and 4D, where much of the interest and seem to reside. At present, physicists expert in that area make fantastic mathematical predictions, some of which are amenable to verification, but which mostly lie outside the range of mathematical intuition or insight. The mathematically rigorous construciton of topological gauge theory in 2D and its interaction with 3D and 4D opens the to a systematic understanding of those mathematically mysterious areas.  

This was one reason why the original project evolved to take on a greater magnitude (with partial results published, and the complete account under completion). A second reason was that a promising long-standing program for the complete understanding of 2D mirror symmetry has run aground on serious obstacles: the reconciliation of higher algebraic structures with the 'anchoring' numerical data mentioned earlier is far more complex and less explicit than originally hoped. The added challenge makes the results more meaningful: they do not quite follow, in the guise initially assumed, as abstract but formal consequences of a few clever observations, but instead encode some important properties of the flag varieties and related spaces with group symmetry. We expect more lessons to emerge as the wider theory is completed.
